section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: Hands-on programming section with exercises focusing on practical implementation of variables and core data types through immediate coding practice and real-world examples
learning_objectives: Declare and assign variables following Python naming conventions
Identify and differentiate between primitive data types in code execution
Convert between numeric and string data types using built-in functions
Manipulate string data using indexing, slicing, and common methods
Perform arithmetic operations while handling type-specific constraints

lessons.lesson_title: Variable Declaration and Primitive Data Types
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will declare variables with valid identifiers and assign values of integer, float, string, and boolean types
key_topics: Variable naming rules and PEP8 conventions
Integer vs float representation in memory
String literal creation with single/double quotes

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create four variables: 'user_age' (integer), 'account_balance' (float), 'full_name' (string), and 'is_active' (boolean). Assign realistic values representing your personal details and print each with a descriptive label.
Analyze these assignments: x = 42, y = '3.14', z = False, w = 0.0. Write comments above each line specifying the exact data type using Python's type terminology.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will convert between string, integer, and float types while verifying conversions using type checking
key_topics: int() and float() conversion edge cases

exercises.exercise_instructions: Convert 98.6 Fahrenheit to Celsius using the formula (F-32)*5/9. Store the result as a float, then convert to integer for whole degrees. Print both values with their types confirmed using type().

Create a program that takes user input for age. Convert the input to integer only if it contains digits, otherwise print 'Invalid age format'. Verify the conversion using type checking before printing.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will modify strings using slicing, concatenation, and built-in methods to solve text processing tasks

exercises.exercise_instructions: Take the string '  user@example.com  '. Remove extra spaces, convert to lowercase, and replace 'example' with 'gmail'. Print the cleaned email address and its length.
Extract the first 5 characters from 'Racecar' using slicing, convert to lowercase, and store in a variable. Print the extracted substring and verify it matches 'race' using boolean comparison.
